ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: student movements, neoliberalism, relational formations, orientalism, mass incarceration, decolonized knowledge formation. how to think about learning, community, each other in a different way that prioritizes our well being

I learned briefly about the history of ethnic studies as a major, both nationally and at Yale. I was introduced to relational formations of race, the argument that ethnic studies analyses must be made in relation and in community within and across marginalized groups.
I solidified my groundwork on the history of ethnic studies and the commitments/interventions it makes across the field!

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: strengths- great professor, great class-- learned so much from my classmate's insightful comments, readings were amazing. one of my favorite classes

strengths- ok syllabus, had good class discussions
weaknesses- course policies did not line up with what we learned in class lol. there is a strict absence policy and late work policy could be more flexible. also a lot of the readings were dense. could also use a more community aspect as i feel i didnt really get to know my peers better despite us all being the same class and major. discussion also felt like lecture a lot. also prof took off points for small conventions errors which was annoying

Strengths  students are presented with a broad range of material to engage with as ethnic studies majors
Improvements  given the large scope of material, changes can be made to the syllabus that ground the material in students' lived experiences, home communities and the local history of ethnic studies in Yale / New Haven. Hopefully this makes for a more engaging and relevant junior seminar for the ER&M major.

The opportunity for community was the greatest strength of this course. It's really meaningful to engage with and learn from ERM peers. I also really enjoyed many of the texts from the syllabus. I would love for class discussion to be a bit more student-led, though.

The main strength of the class to me was being able to spend time with other people in my ER&M cohort and get close to each other. A lot of the texts and materials across the units were familiar to us in different ways, so it was really meaningful to get a sense of grounding in all of it together and do so in a very kind, positive, open environment. Professor Tran is so, so sweet and was radically open to our feedback and dialogue about improving the class as we went along.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, I mean it's required for ER&M majors but it consolidates key themes and ideas that everyone in the major should be familiar on.
only if you have to take it for your major
